title: H2S in Well Control Situation
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you are drilling in the {{currentSection.section}} section where H2S is expected. You take a kick and H2S monitors alarm at {{scenario.h2sLevel}} ppm at the shaker. SIDPP is {{scenario.sidpp}} psi. What additional considerations must be factored into your well control response?

correctConsiderations.action: Muster non-essential personnel, all personnel don SCBA if levels exceed threshold, monitor wind direction
Ensure zinc-based or iron-based scavenger is circulated, increase concentration if needed
Verify BOP, wellhead, and tubulars are H2S-rated (NACE compliant)
H2S is denser than methane - may migrate slower but is more soluble in OBM, could break out suddenly
Notify medic, OIM, and shore-based emergency response. Have antidote available.

answerOptions.A: Proceed with standard well kill - H2S doesn't affect well control procedures
answerOptions.B: Focus solely on personnel evacuation - well control is secondary to H2S safety
answerOptions.C: Integrate personnel protection (SCBA, muster) with well control, ensure scavenger in mud, verify equipment ratings
answerOptions.D: Immediately bullhead to push H2S back into formation

feedback.correct: Correct. H2S adds complexity but doesn't change fundamental well control. You must protect personnel (SCBA, muster non-essential) while continuing well control operations. Ensure H2S scavenger is in the mud and equipment is NACE-rated.
feedback.A_feedback: Incorrect. H2S significantly affects personnel safety protocols during well control. You can't ignore it.
feedback.B_feedback: Incomplete. While personnel safety is critical, abandoning well control could lead to an uncontrolled blowout releasing more H2S. Both must be managed simultaneously.
feedback.D_feedback: Bullheading may be considered but isn't automatic. It could fracture formation or doesn't address the gas already in the wellbore. Controlled circulation with proper PPE is usually preferred.

contextualTip: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, H2S potential in the reservoir means all personnel must be H2S-trained and SCBA must be immediately accessible. During a kick, you're managing TWO emergencies simultaneously.
